passage:
(1) Time zones are a way to standardize time across the globe. Because the Earth rotates, different parts of the world experience daylight and darkness at different times. Before time zones, each town set its own local time based on the position of the sun. This worked fine until the development of faster transportation, like trains, which needed a standardized time system to create schedules. Today, time zones help us coordinate activities like travel, communication, and business across different regions.

(2) The concept of time zones was first proposed by Sir Sandford Fleming in the 1870s. He suggested dividing the world into 24 time zones, each one hour apart. This idea was adopted at the International Meridian Conference in 1884, where the Prime Meridian in Greenwich, England, was chosen as the starting point for time zones. This is why we have Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) as a reference point for time around the world.

(3) The Earth is divided into 24 time zones, each covering 15 degrees of longitude. As you move east, the time advances by one hour per time zone, and as you move west, it goes back by one hour. For example, if it's 12:00 PM in London (GMT), it's 7:00 AM in New York (GMT-5) and 9:00 PM in Tokyo (GMT+9). However, not all time zones are exactly one hour apart; some countries use half-hour or quarter-hour differences.

(4) There are exceptions to the standard time zone system. Many countries observe Daylight Saving Time (DST), where clocks are set forward by one hour during the summer months to make better use of daylight. Additionally, some countries, like China, have a single time zone despite spanning multiple geographical time zones. This can lead to unusual situations, such as the sun rising and setting at the same time across a large country.

(5) Time zones are crucial in our interconnected world. They affect international travel, as flight schedules must account for time differences. Global businesses rely on time zones to coordinate meetings and operations across different countries. Even something as simple as scheduling a phone call with a friend in another country requires an understanding of time zones. Without them, coordinating time across the globe would be chaotic and confusing.
